q: What are the symptoms of lichen sclerosus?
a: The symptoms of lichen sclerosus include itchy white patches on the genitals or other parts of the body. The patches are usually itchy, white, smooth or wrinkled, and easily damaged.

q: How can lichen sclerosus be managed?
a: To manage lichen sclerosus, you can wash with an emollient soap substitute, dab your genitals dry, apply a barrier cream, wear cotton or silk underwear, and use vaginal lubricant if sex is uncomfortable.

q: When should I see a doctor for lichen sclerosus?
a: You should see a doctor if you have an itchy white patch on your genitals or skin, if treatment is not helping, or if you have pain when going to the toilet or having sex.

q: What is the treatment for lichen sclerosus?
a: Lichen sclerosus cannot be cured, but prescription steroid cream is usually recommended to relieve the symptoms. The cream needs to be used regularly for a few months to get the symptoms under control.

q: Can lichen sclerosus cause complications?
a: Yes, lichen sclerosus can cause complications such as scarring and tightness of the affected skin. This can lead to discomfort during urination, bowel movements, and sex. In severe cases, surgery may be necessary to address these complications.

q: Does lichen sclerosus increase the risk of cancer?
a: Yes, lichen sclerosus increases the risk of cancer on the vulva, penis, or anus. It's important to regularly check yourself for any lumps, changes in skin texture, or persistent ulcers, and consult a doctor if you're concerned.

q: What causes lichen sclerosus?
a: The exact cause of lichen sclerosus is unknown, but it is believed to be related to the immune system mistakenly attacking and damaging the skin. It is not contagious and is not caused by poor personal hygiene.

q: Are there any age or gender factors associated with lichen sclerosus?
a: Lichen sclerosus can affect people of all ages, including children, but it is more common in women over 50. It can occur in individuals with different skin colors.

q: What are the common affected areas of lichen sclerosus?
a: The common affected areas of lichen sclerosus include the area around the opening to the vagina (vulva) and anus, as well as the foreskin and end of the penis.
